basics.name: Jason Flatford
basics.label: Chief Product & Technology Leader — SaaS | AI | Platform Scaling
basics.summary: Product & technology executive spanning event operations, SaaS product development, and emerging AI platforms. First SaaS delivery was Concierge (internal tournament management) at StarCityGames.com. Scaled Melee.gg from concept to a global esports+events platform (≈400k users, ≈70k MAUs, ≈13k organizer partners), architecting a multi‑tenant codebase with real‑time analytics, multilingual support, and PCI‑compliant payments. Founder of Duly (civic‑tech; soft‑launch, no active users) and Memnai (AI‑driven reporting, in development). Hands‑on across architecture and delivery (.NET/C#, Java/Kotlin/Spring Boot, React/React Native) and cloud (AWS, Azure, Terraform, Docker).

work.name: Keyrune Inc. / Melee.gg
work.summary: Led product strategy and hands‑on platform architecture for a global esports/events SaaS.
highlights: Scaled the platform to ≈400k registered users, ≈70k MAUs, and ≈13k B2B organizer partners with limited funding.
Owned end‑to‑end product lifecycle: discovery → roadmap → delivery → iteration, balancing partner needs and PLG signals.
Architected multi‑tenant SaaS (>2M LoC) with modular services: registration, decklists, pairings, standings, ticketing/payments, analytics, audit logging.
Implemented real‑time features with SignalR and WebSockets; built live ops dashboards for events and support.
Implemented multilingual/i18n framework and regionalization of payments and tax/VAT handling.
Designed and enforced security baselines: least‑privilege IAM, secrets management, audit trails.
PCI‑aware payments with Stripe; chargeback handling and reconciliation workflows.
Cloud migration and infra hardening: Azure → AWS; ECS, RDS (MariaDB), Redis, CloudWatch, Secrets Manager; IaC with Terraform; CDN/WAF via Cloudflare.
Observability: structured logging (Serilog), metrics and alerting; on‑call runbooks and incident communications.
AI augmentation: OpenAI‑assisted analytics and internal tooling; reduced manual operations and improved support SLAs.
Partnered with global brands (Wizards of the Coast, Disney, Red Bull) to unlock adoption and co‑marketing opportunities.
Collaborated with CEO on investor materials and growth narrative; aligned roadmap to fund‑raising milestones.
Built lightweight microservice patterns and code health standards; mentored contributors and contractors.
Forged alliances with Ravensburger and Fantasy Flight Games alongside Wizards of the Coast to support Disney Lorcana and Star Wars: Unlimited programs.
Directed global rollout in 8 languages; maintained 99.99%+ uptime across cloud-native architecture.
Launched a modular CMS to support content/program operations.

work.name: Flattsware LLC
work.summary: Formed to build and operate Melee.gg as the flagship product for online MTG Arena tournaments. Exclusively focused on Melee until Flattsware transitioned into Keyrune Incorporated in 2022 (assets migrated; continued as EVP of Product).
highlights: Public launch of Melee (Mar 2020); early growth of ~1,000 users/week and 5,400 players served by Apr 2020.
Signed contract with Wizards of the Coast (Jul 2020); produced $250,000 Mythic Invitational, Players Tour Finals, Season Grand Finals, and Zendikar Rising Championship.
Operated the largest independently run MTG Arena online tournament for Red Bull Untapped (2,466 players); Red Bull Untapped Series totaled ~15,106 players.
Ran SCG Tour Online Series on Melee: Series 1 ($53k revenue; 287 tournaments; 3,285 players), Series 2 ($57k; 215 tournaments; 3,928 players), Series 3 ($56k; 99 tournaments; 13,633 players).
Global adoption: tournaments from every continent (except Antarctica) and users from 85 countries by Oct 2020.
Usage milestones: 50,000 matches played (Jul 2020); 100,000 (Sep/Oct 2020); 27,000 users / 3,000 tournaments / 160,000 matches (Dec 2020).
Launched public decklist database (Aug 2020) and reached ~2 million MTG cards registered.
Introduced Japanese language support (Feb 2021).
Release cadence: ~3 website updates per month post-launch.
Identified market gap for decklist ingestion & validation and built the core workflows end-to-end.
Sole developer through the early lifecycle; recruited Steve Port (CEO) and Brad Nelson (marketing/content) to scale operations.

work.name: Foresite LLC
work.location: Manchester, CT & Roanoke, VA (Hybrid: on-site + remote)
work.summary: Built the portal UI/UX and automation for classifying network device audit logs and managing rules; developed supporting services and tooling across Groovy/Grails and Java (Spring), with PostgreSQL as the primary datastore.
highlights: Owned UI/UX for the audit-log classification workflow and the rules management console (Drools).
Built internal tools in Grails, Groovy, and Java to accelerate classification and reduce manual effort.
Developed Java microservices with Spring to automate parsing, normalization, and routing of audit logs.
Implemented PostgreSQL schemas and queries tuned for high-volume log classification workloads.
Delivered rich data-grid experiences with JavaScript, jQuery, DataTables, and Bootstrap for analysts and operators.
Collaborated with security/compliance stakeholders to ensure auditable workflows and reliable operations.

work.name: StarCityGames.com
work.position: Event Representative → Coordinator of Event Operations & Technical Lead
work.summary: Started as an event representative administering in-person Magic: The Gathering events and producing venue table layouts (~30 events/year). Evolved into technical lead after GP Richmond, teaching myself VBA → Visual Basic → C# and building internal tooling (Print Assistant, Genesis POS) culminating in Concierge. Served as Event Lead for multiple Open Series events, owning logistics end-to-end, staff coordination, training, deployments, and on-site troubleshooting.
highlights: Produced table layouts and handled venue/vendor liaison logistics for nearly 30 events per year during the first two years.
Served as Event Lead for Open Series events, owning operations from departure to return; managed 6–12 person admin teams, finances, and customer service.
Built the Print Assistant to transform structured player data into printable/postable outputs.
Built Genesis an internal POS-style event management tool that preceded Concierge.
Designed and launched Concierge to centralize registration/check-in, seating/pairings, staffing, badge printing/scanning, cash reconciliation, and reporting.
Standardized training, deployments, and on-site triage for Concierge; enabled any staffer to service any player with full context.
Redesigned registration flows that eliminated long lines seen at peak events (e.g., Richmond).
Partnered with leadership to iterate table layout, timing, and admin policies—streamlining player experience and event throughput.

work.name: Eagle Boat Docks
work.summary: Sole drafter and designer across a jack-of-all-trades marina operation—commercial marinas, structural steel fabrication, and boat lifts. Owned costing, design/engineering, vendor liaison, and QA on multi-million-dollar projects; drove component innovations that cut cost and boosted quality.
highlights: Architected and engineered several multi-million-dollar commercial marina projects from concept through fabrication.
Led project costing and produced quotes, scopes of work, and proposals for marinas, docks, boat lifts, and solar add-ons.
Introduced design innovations to boat-dock components that reduced production cost while improving quality and durability.
Established and ran QA processes for structural steel and marina fabrications.
Designed boat lifts and managed the design-to-fabrication handoff.
Vendor liaison and purchasing owner for structural steel and flotation materials.

work.name: Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA)
work.summary: Traced and maintained detailed plant drawings; built early exposure to large‑scale energy systems.
highlights: Developed precision drafting skills and documentation discipline in a regulated environment.

projects.name: Melee.gg
projects.description: Esports/events SaaS built to run large-scale Magic: The Gathering tournaments (online & in-person): registration, decklists, pairings, standings, payments, analytics, and live ops.
highlights: Scaled to ≈400k registered users, ≈70k MAUs, and ≈13k organizer partners with a lean team.
Originated at Flattsware (2019) as an ASP.NET MVC (C#) app on Azure to run MTG Arena events; later operated under Keyrune.
Delivered 99.99%+ uptime and an 8-language rollout; global usage across 80+ countries.
Largest independently run MTG Arena online tournament for Red Bull Untapped (≈2,400 players); additional Untapped series events (~15k players total).
Hosted professional events for Wizards of the Coast during the COVID era (online/hybrid Pro Tours).
SCG Tour Online operations with hundreds of tournaments and six-figure revenue across three series.
Launched public decklist database; reached ~2M MTG cards registered and >100k matches within months of launch.
Multi-tenant architecture (>2M LoC) with RBAC, audit logging, and admin/live-ops dashboards.
Real-time features (SignalR/WebSockets) for pairings, standings, and event control.
PCI-aware payments via Stripe including chargeback handling and financial reconciliation.
OpenAI-assisted analytics and internal tooling that reduced manual ops and improved support SLAs.
Alliances/partnerships with Wizards of the Coast, Disney, Red Bull, Ravensburger (Disney Lorcana), and Fantasy Flight Games (Star Wars: Unlimited).
Infrastructure evolution: Azure → AWS (ECS, RDS/MariaDB, Redis, CloudWatch, Secrets Manager), Terraform/IaC, Cloudflare WAF/CDN.
Launched a modular CMS to support content/program operations; maintained a steady post-launch release cadence.

projects.name: Duly
projects.description: Civic-engagement platform designed to make constituent communications more transparent and approachable—especially for younger voters. Gives elected officials tools to ingest and manage constituent messages while publishing public, privacy-safe summaries.
highlights: Soft-launched; shown to multiple elected officials; currently paused while focusing on job search.
Enables verified offices to ingest constituent messages and publish public summaries for transparency.
Goal: onboard elected officials’ offices as first organizations; resources are the current blocker.

projects.name: Memnai
projects.description: Prototype interface that lets non-SQL users query and manage relational data using natural language. The AI generates SQL within role-based guardrails so users can safely read/write, import/export data, and create tables according to permissions.
highlights: Prototype only; not launched; currently paused.
Natural-language → SQL with RBAC guardrails for safe reads/writes.
Planned stack: Spring Boot + Kotlin backend, React frontend; supports schema/metadata injection and query previews.

projects.name: Concierge
projects.description: Internal, admin-only tournament management platform for large-scale Magic: The Gathering events (registration, staffing, logistics, reporting).
highlights: First full-scale production deployment at Grand Prix London (Apr 30–May 1, 2011).
Cleared a ~100-person registration line in ~10 minutes and maintained effectively zero wait time for the rest of the 3-day event.
Replaced prior Google Docs workflow that caused building-length queues at peak events (Richmond).
Used across SCG Grand Prix and SCG Open Series; served ≈100,000 total attendees; used by hundreds of contractors and an ~11-person internal ops team.
Admin-only design: any staffer could service any player with full context, significantly improving customer service and first-touch resolution.
Key modules: registration & check-in; badge assignment/printing/scanning; seating & pairings; staffing; POS-style ticket issuance (no payment processing); cash reconciliation; reporting/BI.
Architecture/stack: .NET (C#) with WPF on Windows; MySQL; on-prem servers; role-based access control (RBAC) and audit logs.

projects.name: The Endless Grimoire
projects.description: Mobile clicker/idle game prototype. All in-game content is AI-generated. Primary objective was to build hands-on experience with React, React Native, and mobile design.
highlights: Prototype stage; not launched; currently paused.
All content AI-generated to enable a very large content set.
Personal learning project to deepen React/React Native/mobile-design skills.

volunteer.summary: Volunteered ~5–6 years as a Level 3 judge (≈110 of ~6,000 judges at the time). Regional leadership in the Mid-Atlantic; team lead/head judge at premier events; member of the Player Investigations Committee; mentor/examiner for new judges; conference presenter.
highlights: Led or team-led ~100+ events across the U.S., Europe, Central America, Canada, and Hawaii; recognized for on-site crisis management and de-escalation.
One of a small global cohort of Level 3 judges responsible for event leadership, policy interpretation, and program contributions.
Member of the Player Investigations Committee (post-DQ reviews, penalty/suspension recommendations).
Mentored, trained, and certified ~30 judges (L1/L2); authored training materials and delivered seminars (incl. player investigation/anti-cheating).
Deep rules/policy expertise (MTR, IPG, JAR); known for clear player communication and conflict resolution.
Regular team leadership at Grand Prix/Pro Tour-level events, including Pro Tour Sundays.

conflictHandling.rule: Prefer user's latest statement; keep previous as context; use ranges or 'approx.' when needed; never invent.

Melee.gg.note: Originated at Flattsware; later under Keyrune

Concierge.note: Grand Prix London; Richmond anecdote is context

formattingAtsRules: Bullets = action + scope + metric; keep concise and scannable.
Use active voice; present tense for current, past for previous.
Mirror JD keywords naturally; avoid keyword stuffing.
Prefer concrete numbers and ranges; avoid unverified superlatives.
Clean headings; short paragraphs; bold key metrics in export formats.

principles: Master JSON is the source for all resumes, letters, and profiles.
Use schema fields correctly: impacts in 'highlights', short role summary in 'summary', stacks in 'keywords'.

consistentFields.educationNote: Add courses note indicating bachelor’s-equivalent+ professional experience (15+ years).

contentPlaybook.resume2Page: Executive summary; 4–6 bullets for Keyrune/Melee, 2–4 for Flattsware, 2–3 for Foresite/SCG; single-line early roles; grouped skills; trimmed interests; include LinkedIn and website.
contentPlaybook.tailoredVersions: Mirror JD phrasing in keywords/highlights; surface domain-relevant projects; spotlight compliance (HIPAA/SOC-2/PCI) when applicable.
contentPlaybook.coverLetters: 120–180 words; hook with a relevant metric + why-us + concrete value; no fluff.
contentPlaybook.founderPitch: Emphasize scrappy scaling, partnerships, and product-led growth.

researchVerification.principle: Prefer user's account when reputable sources disagree on minor details; never include confidential/NDA data.

do: Quantify outcomes; show ownership and constraints (small team, limited funding).
Highlight repeatable systems (roadmaps, runbooks, incident comms).
Keep language simple, specific, and business-relevant.
dont: Personal health details or negative commentary about employers.
Unverified claims, vague statements, or over-designed PDFs that hurt ATS.
operatingBehaviors: Deliver complete outputs in the current response.
If a request is complex/ambiguous, make a best-effort pass and note assumptions.
Maintain a professional, confident, approachable tone; avoid filler.

Proactive guardrails: if the user suggests something counterproductive or an anti-pattern (e.g., ATS-unfriendly formatting, keyword stuffing, misleading titles/dates), flag it succinctly, explain the risk, propose a better alternative with an example, proceed with the best-practice version by default (while preserving the original idea), and if the user still prefers their approach, implement it while noting trade-offs.
